newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan denies anti-missile system plan with U.S..
newsitem.headline: Taiwan denies anti-missile system plan with U.S..

text.p: Defence Minister Chiang Ching-ling on Wednesday denied a newspaper report that Taiwan and the United States were evaluating possible deployment of a joint anti-missile system on the island.
"What the newspaper said is not correct," Chiang said on state-funded television.
"There is no such thing. It's just a newspaper report," Chiang told reporters when asked about the report.
The United Daily News, quoting unnamed generals, said the system, which also would protect Japan and South Korea, was discussed at a secret meeting in early September.
Officials routinely deny reports about Taiwan weapons development and military contacts with foreign countries.
The latest report could not be confirmed independently and it was not known if it was related to Taiwan's planned purchase of U.S.-made anti-missile missiles.
The mass-circulation United Daily News said planning for the missile defence system was sparked by a series of intimidating military manoeuvres mounted by arch-rival China since mid-1995.

"Both the U.S. side and we feel the emergent need to establish an anti-missile system after communist China's two rounds of missile tests targeting Taiwan last year and this year," the newspaper quoted the generals as saying.
The report did not say where the meeting was held or whether concrete conclusions were reached.
China launched a nine-month series of war games and missile tests off Taiwan after President Lee Teng-hui's private but high-profile visit to the United States in June 1995.
Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province not entitled to foreign ties since a civil war split them in 1949.
China's missile tests prompted Washington to send two aircraft carriers near the Taiwan strait to monitor the crisis during Taiwan's March presidential election.
Beijing maintains a standing threat to recover the island by force if it opts for independence. Both governments say they want reunification, but under very different terms.

Under pressure from China, Taiwan has faced difficulties in purchasing advanced weapons from the West but the United States, which switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1979, asserts a right to provide the island defensive weapons.

In 1993 Washington said Taiwan planned a private purchase from U.S. defence giant Raytheon Co. of a "modified air defence system" based on the Gulf War-tested Patriot anti-missile missile in a deal estimated at $175 million.
